speaker: Donald Trump
vclaim: Because of Obamakari, people's premiums are up 35.45.55%.
date: stated on October 25, 2015 in comments on ABC's "This Week":
title: Trump: Obama health care premiums for health care rise 35, 45, 55%
text: Donald Trump Ben Carson will not apologize for questioning the neurosurgeon religion, but he agrees with Carson's ideas about health care. Trump, who is tracking Carson in the new polls in Iowa, suggested on the electoral campaign track that Carson's Seventh Day Adventist faith was not "down the middle of the road." When Trump appeared in EBC this week, he said that he "didn't say anything bad" about Carson, described Carson's personal health-saving account proposal as a "very good idea," and took the opportunity to drop another discount. On October 25, Trump said: "People's premiums are not known if you've been watching lately over the last two weeks, increasing by 35, 45, 55 percent. "It's so high that no one's ever gonna use it." So... Obama Kira's become a bigger disaster than anyone thought." On average, premiums have increased by some 5.8 per cent annually since Obama took office, compared with 13.2 per cent in the nine years preceding Obama. Is it true that we will see that insurance schemes rose by between 35 and 55 percent in 2016? We contacted the Trump campaign, but we didn't hear anything about it. The experts we talked to and the data show that although there are examples of such significant increases, they are not the rule. Let us begin with a timely help from the great lifting. Under the Affordable Care Act, insurance companies that plan to increase their rates by more than 10 per cent are required to submit their proposals for federal review. In many states, companies also have to negotiate their prices with a government insurance commissioner. Overall, the final instalments will be equal to or less than the proposed rates, according to Larry Levitt of the Kaiser Family Foundation, a leading non-partisan health policy research centre. With five days left before open registration began in November, the rates are likely to have been approved or adjusted, but not all have been announced. Trump has a point that some insurance companies have requested increases up to two high numbers. "Yeah, some people in some plans through some carriers in some states actually look at average heights from "35 to 50 per cent" if they stick to those plans in 2016," said Charles Gabba, who runs the ACAsincips.net, which tracks Obamacare's registration. "This isn't entirely from the wall. Many popular plans have requested substantial increases," Gail Wilinski, Health Economist, Head of Medical Care and Medicaid, said under George H.W. (Bosch) "These picnics will affect people more than some might think." She noted that Blue Cross Blue Selder, a prominent insurance company with a large number of registered persons, had proposed an increase of 14 to 38 per cent in Illinois and 50 to 65 per cent in New Mexico. But that doesn't tell the whole story either, according to the data. :: A much lower average of only 7% of all plans on the Federal Exchange had a proposed 30% or higher price increase, Agile Health Insurance Estimates, which regards itself as "an easy alternative to Obama ' s care." This translates into average increases at much lower levels than Tramp said. If we look at the final rates of the lowest and second lowest market cost plans in the silver category - which forms the basis for federal premium subsidies and is selected by 68 per cent of those registered - the average increase is hardly 35 to 55 per cent. The Kaiser Family Foundation found that the cost of a standard silver scheme would be on average 4.4 per cent more expensive across major cities in 13 states and Washington, D.C. (again, this is a smaller annual increase than before Obama became the Care Act). The distinguished fact-finding bloggers mentioned on January 10, 2021 in the story of "The Rebel Law - General Flynn will be appointed Vice-President." • January 11, 2012, according to Kaiser, those enrolled in Minneapolis will see the largest increase in the allowance of 28.7 percent. At the other end of the spectrum, plans will actually be reduced by 10.4 per cent in Seattle. If we look at both the final and the required rates, Trump's number is still very high. ACASGINups.net anticipates an increase in the national average of 12 to 13 per cent across 49 states and Washington, D.C. (no data on Wisconsin). This is consistent with Associated Press estimates, which increase the number of projects in one high to the low number of adolescents. According to the estimates of Gabba, only three states are on foot near the level claimed by Tramp: Alaska, Hawaii and Minnesota. "I don't see any reasonable way for the average high rate to be anywhere close to 35 per cent, and certainly not any higher," said Gabba. Not all the experts we talked to warned us that there was a great divergence from plan to plan, from region to region, from insurance to insurance. This is why neither Tramp's claim nor averages tell the whole story. The disparity in price increases is more likely for insurers to make adjustments, rather than providing evidence that Obama's welfare programme is a "disaster," according to Trump. After all, 2016 is the first year that insurance companies consider actual claims data rather than "think what their costs are primarily," as Livit said from Kaiser. "Some insurers have guessed better than others, leading to changes in allowances." The figures are different from case to case, affecting the risk pool and changes in premiums. Increases in the premium rate can also be unique to individual circumstances and do not necessarily reflect a national average. "A number of factors can lead to consumer allowance that differs from average rate change, including changes in age, tobacco status, geography, benefit design, family status and eligibility for subsidy," according to a summary prepared by the American Academy of Actuaries. To understand what the typical increase in the rate is, we don't just have to wait until the final rates show up. "You must have a weighted average until we know only after the truth," said Wilinski. At the same time, experts recommend that everyone verify their own rates. Our Governor Trump said, "People's premiums... rise 35, 45, 55 percent." Some Federal Stock Exchange insurance schemes will see prices rise at the levels proposed by Trump. But he's picking up cherry in the high end of the next excellent changes. The estimates for the national average are significantly lower than the Trump figures, which range from 4.4 per cent to 13 per cent. Trump's claim is partially accurate, but it is out of context. We value it half right.
